Been playing for like a year and a half and I still suck at jungle pathing really hard lol

I'm coming up on five years I believe. Best jungle path I've found, and take almost every game. Take your buff (red is absolute best for this strat unless your champ straight up can't function wihtout blue like amumu or fiddlesticks, for this we will assume you started red), don't use smite on the opening buff just tough it out, go immediately to the enemy blue. Here you will have about three options. 1) the enemy blue is still there, ward across the jun wall and proceed to take the blue
2) the blue is gone. In this case go around the corner to their gromp. Most of the time you'll find some goofball there with no smite left up cause he used it on blue and something like 1/3rd remaning health. Use your smite on the gromp to get your hp back once it's in kill range while you proceed to beat the piss out of the other jungler. They either die or bail, not much else they can do.
3) there is no blue and gromp is still there. Just clear their jun. You might find them at wolves. If so, treat it like step 2. On your way out grab the scuttle. ALWAYS GRAB THE SCUTTLES.

after that you can basically just do whatever you want in whichever jungle as long as you are aware of enemy laner locations. Don't be afraid to use dashes and gap closers to cross walls instead of going around. Backtrack as little as possible, and always be looking for chances to fuck with enemies, especially their jun. Your job isn't so much to kill enemies and take things as it is to try to tilt as many enemies off the face of the planet as you possibly can. Also, enemies who talk in all chat (except the really light hearted people that are obviously just having a good time with the full game of players, you can tell the difference) are more likely to rage. Usually you can tilt that guy and it becomes an autowin more or less.
Ah yes use this strat, I like people that wander into my jungle when so early, because usually that's a death sentence.

Like [this](https://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/featured/new-player-guide)?

This is the big one. My friends have been playing for upwards two years (and more), but I usually end up telling them what to build; they're playing video games, not reading about that kid we learned of in math class. Half the items in the game are goddam percentages, nobody wants to sit there and work that out, or decide if 30% is going to be helpful or a waste of money.

The big issue is League's community. Wanting to improve, learning, all these things-- when they're not tryhard, they're simply unanswered. I've literally been in games trying to actively engage the other four players to try and find what we can do to win only to be met by total silence.

League's community is trash. It's absolute goddam garbage, where you can get shit for doing well. In no other game has doing well been responded to with negativity on my own team. But in League, it'll happen. Just because the players are that puerile and shitty.

The new experience is largely what you make of it bringing players in. Lucky me, I've been playing MOBA-styled maps since about 2005 or 2006; coming to League in 2013 for S3 was about as easy a transition as any, though it took me a good year to wrap my head around build orders, priorities, and how to properly deal with Lux. When I brought my players in, I stressed a simple idea; it's better to live than to die in virtually any situation.

There is no 'new player experience' in League. Smurfs, bot accounts, trolls, and more new people who only sort of have a vague idea of what's going on. It's a nightmare and Riot doesn't want to acknowledge it because they're having troubles enough dealing with the game at the upper echelons-- over a hundred items and champions means balance is going to be a complete mess whatever happens. None of the commanding concepts ever get an explanation, but you get flamed if you don't adhere to them. You ever seen someone running something totally meta and thought, "God, they just have no idea how to do that"? Youtubers are as close to explanations as you get and they'll be a reference at best, but since it's an answer, it's what people take. There's more to the game than any one component, but they don't ever treat it like the sum of its parts; they take parts separately. Like bots.

League of Legends is breaking. They refuse to admit it because it would look bad; they refuse to do anything because of the sheer work put ahead of that task. It will slowly fade out over the next two years, before it meets a quiet, unfortunate end. Not with a bang, but with a fizzle and a pop. Like pop rocks! Mmm.
'No other game' in other words, just about every other MOBA. MOBA's in general have communities straight outta hell...

Honestly all big popular gaming communities will have plenty of toxic players. Leagues community isnt really that special when it comes to that. Not to mention even how champ abilities are worded is just garbage and doesn't really explain to you how to use them, take a new player trying Vi for example, odds are they don't know you have to hold Q down to make it go farther, because the ability description DOESN'T TELL YOU TO. This is UNACCEPTABLY bad, and hers is a fairly simple example. Rumbles ult for new player is damn near impossible to use correctly until a human being tells them how to use the damn thing, because again the description doesn't tell you how to use it.
Yeah, I was taking aatrox mid when I got him, as I still had no Idea what meta was.  I was only playing AI games, and thought that there are literally 2 people top, 1 mid, and 2 bot

Fortunately for me, that one friend who referred me was a jungle main, so that was straightened out for me right off the bat... he mained Ekko jungle, AP because Tank Ekko wasn't quite a thing yet, and was like level 20. He'd probably only been playing for like a month when he referred me. I legit went Sivir mid in a bot custom with him, did next to nothing, and watched the Zilean bot carry us hard. He made a joke I didn't get once about Galio support, and the instant Galio came on free week I played like three games a day of Galio support, rushing Athene's after Targon's Brace and then just like stacking health and mana regen because I didn't like the idea of running out of stuff and because I had really bad mana problems because I was using Q and E for waveclear as the support (and I expect you know how bad old Galio's mana costs could be if you didn't respect them). Hit mastery 4 like that. Then he left free week and I mained Janna playing her like she was Sion. I always charged my Q. Can't remember if I even knew that I could release it early. I just left it in the middle of lane and hoped it hit someone at max range. Always used W active to proc Spellthief's, never basic attacked. I never peeled either, I just went straight in. I'd just walk into the enemy team (pretty sure I didn't have Flash unlocked yet) and try to knock them into my team with ult. Meanwhile I was trying to do a full clear as AD Zilean jungle in a custom, because I thought his Q was only useful for clearing the jungle, and even if I landed it on someone it did seemingly no damage; I actually thought that having an AoE stun was like a prerequisite for being able to jungle healthily because the only jungler I'd ever watched clear was Ekko. Furthermore, I couldn't navigate the shop at all, so I just got an item set for everything off mobafire if I couldn't think of one myself, including three for Kassadin, whom I immediately committed to mastering. Five games after buying him blind I realized that I was the worst Kassadin player in the history of the game because I couldn't manage his mana and I always went in hard on everything as soon as I hit level 6, used Q to farm, always held E really long, and thought his passive and Q shield made him literally unkillable by mages. Later, I bought Galio and actually figured out that I wasn't good at him. Somewhere along the line I bought Swain on patch 6.9, and that's about where I "stopped being bad". I legitimately wasn't even vaguely competent at this game until I started abusing something completely and utterly broken. And even then, from time to time I played Kassadin...

omg please, don't bring up old Galio's mana costs, I'm experiencing PTSD.
And the worst story I've got is that I had ashe and I build like, 3 Seeker's armguards because I thought "Ability power, make my abilities do more damage, sweet! and armor? oh GOD I'll be unstoppable"  Yeah I was very, very misled by the tutorial xD

The point of the tutorial is to teach players how to play the game. If the tutorial can't teach someone the bare basics of auto-attacking minions, either the tutorial has a problem or the player has a problem. It's literally teaching someone how to click on things, not how to freeze a wave or splitpush effectively. Even I, at the height of my idiocy and having never played a MOBA before, could at least understand that clicking made me move and auto. The whole point of a tutorial is to teach a new player the controls. If the tutorial is unable to teach a player the simplest thing they can do in pretty much any game (their move controls) to where the tutorial needs a safety net in case the player can't do it, then it's a really lackluster tutorial.

Yes that is the tutorial you are forced to build thornmails there.

It's so that the player doesn't somehow fail the tutorial if they don't attack the minions. Thornmail kills the minions regardless.
